results.title: The Right person for the job
results.brief_description: Excerpts from a seminar held on equal rights legislation held at Trinity College, Melbourne University, are interspersed with dramatisations of problems which women face in the workforce. Shows the role of the conciliation officer and the hearing of a discrimination case by the Equal Opportunity Board

results.title: Don't Think I Don't Think
results.brief_description: Documents an important conference on rights for the disabled held at Melbourne University in 1981. The disabled groups present drew up a charter of rights- rights to work, to live in their own houses etc. free of the constraints that paternalistic institutions impose

results.title: The Solar House:  a Lifestyle for the Future
results.creator_credit: Harrison Solar Houses and New South Wales Energy Authority
results.brief_description: Discusses the various ways a typical suburban house can be more energy efficient, including solar energy, solid concrete slabs and insulation.

results.title: The Ghost in the shed
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, Nick Bosustow and Bosustow Entertainment
results.brief_description: A whimsical story of a polite but persistent ghost of a secretly buried murder victim. His attempts to draw attention to his remains mystify the family in the house. Based on the book by Marilynne K. Roach.

results.title: Victoria's Energy
results.creator_credit: Dept of Minerals and Energy AV Workshop

results.title: The Models
results.creator_credit: Ray Argall, John Cruthers and Musical Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Pop Movie”.
Melbourne new wave band “The Models” are shown performing live at Bombay Rock and discussing their music, record contracts and attraction for playing in a rock band. Filmed on the eve of the release of their first album.

results.title: Home on the range: U.S. bases in Australia
results.creator_credit: Gil Scrine and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Examines the existence of U.S. military bases in Australia and how their presence has affected its position in the nuclear arms race between the Soviet Union and America. Considers the question of nuclear arms in Australia in terms of the presence of the C.I.A. in Australia, its manipulation on the course of Australia’s political affairs and the mounting opposition by the general public. Script: Gil Scrine, Bob Connolly, David Bradbury Narrated by Annie Webster, David Ritchie
results.title_for_label: Home on the range: U.S. bases in Australia

results.title: Bread and dripping
results.creator_credit: Women's Film Collective, Margot Nash and Wimins Films
results.brief_description: The role of the women during the Great Depression has often been neglected in the telling of Australian history. Using archival footage, this film illustrates the hardships and the political struggles women faced in a time of political and economic upheaval.
